body.p: The lymphatic system functions on many levels in the following ways. Pick the correct answer.

input.choice: It produces antigens that stimulate the inflammatory cells to come in and identify pathogens, which are then cleaned up by lymph vessels and sent to the spleen for degradation.

The B cells produce antibodies against specific pathogens when the antigen is combined with the proper MHC markers on the cell. Antibodies help to clump together the invading organisms and make them more susceptible for phagocytosis. The large debris of dead and dying cells is moved into the lymph capillaries, where it is further cleaned by lymph nodes and the spleen.
When a tissue is torn or damaged in some fashion, mast cells release granules containing complement. Complement binds to the damaged tissue and stimulates to regrow, resulting in healing.

All cells present the appropriate MHC markers. When the MHC markers are missing the Helper -T cells come in and make more MHC proteins which are used to send the aberrant cells back to the thymus for further education.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Antigens are molecules recognized by the immune system.
Correct.
Incorrect. Mast cell granules contain histamine which stimulates the inflammatory response.

Incorrect. Helper T cells do not make MHC proteins. MHC proteins are made by each individual cell and put on the cell membrane with MHC proteins produced by individual cells and expressed on the cell membrane after assembly.

body.p: Which of the following statements is correct?

input.choice: Histamine is a small molecule that stimulates the production of interferons, which are proteins made by virally infected cells to stimulate healthy neighboring cells to inhibit viral replication.
Complement proteins are made by the liver and stimulate the inflammatory process to make more white blood cells.
Transferrins pick up iron in the blood, which is then used to stimulate macrophages to divide.
Opsonization may result from the activation of the complement pathway.

feedback.p: Incorrect Histamine stimulates the inflammatory response.
Complement is used in opsonization and to stimulate mast cells to released more histamine, but they do not stimulate the production of white blood cells.
Incorrect. Macrophages do not require iron as stimulus for division.
Correct. One of the roles of complement is to facilitate phagocytosies by opsonization.

body.p: The molecules that regulate the immune system represent several classes of biomolecules. Which pair is NOT correct?

input.choice: Prostaglandins are proteins originally found in the prostate gland.
Leukotrienes belong to a group called eicosanoids.
Some complement proteins have enzymatic activity.
Histamine is a small molecule that contains an amine group.

feedback.p: Correct. Prostaglandins are inflammatory mediators unrelated to the prostate gland.
Incorrect. This statement is true.
Incorrect. This statement is true.
Incorrect. This statement is true.

body.p: Fill in the blank: Histamine, __________ complement, prostaglandins, and leukotrienes can directly stimulate the inflammatory response.

input.choice: MHC antigens
Antibodies
Kinins
PAMPs

feedback.p: Incorrect. MHC proteins are found on the surface of somatic cells, and do not stimulate inflammation directly.
Incorrect. Antibodies bind to antigens and do not directly stimulate the inflammatory response.
Correct. Kinins together with the other mediators act in the inflammatory response.
Incorrect. PAMPs can initiate the innate immune response, but are not direct stimulators of the inflammatory response.

body.p: The innate immune response would use which of the following combinations of molecules as part of its defense system?

input.choice: Antibodies, kinins, MHC proteins, and histamine
Interferon, iron-binding proteins, complement, and anti-microbial proteins
Cytokines, interferon, prostaglandins , leukotrienes
PRRs, leukotrienes, interferon and complement

feedback.p: Incorrect. None of these is involved in the innate immune response.
Correct. Those are all components of the innate response.
Incorrect. Leukotrienes and prostaglandins stimulate the inflammatory response.
Incorrect. Leukotrienes stimulate the inflammatory response.

body.p: The adaptive immune system needs to be able to __________________ to function correctly.

input.choice: recognize foreign molecules bound to red blood cells
use PAMPs as receptors for macrophage binding
recognize foreign proteins associated with the body’s own self markers
produce IgM as part of the immune response to antigens that the body has encountered previously

feedback.p: Incorrect. The foreign molecules must be bound to cells exhibiting the appropriate MHC proteins (red blood cells do not present MHC).
Incorrect.PAMPs are repeated molecular patterns recognized by the innate immune system .
Correct. Recognition of non-self molecules has to happen in association with MHC antigens, the body’s self antigens.
Incorrect. IgM is the major antibody found during the primary adaptive immune response.

body.p: Pattern recognition receptors (PRR) are part of the innate immune response and are found on ___________.

input.choice: Neutrophils, mast cells, and macrophages
B cells, T cells, and Cytotoxic T cells
Thymus cells, dendritic, cells, and neutrophils
Dendritic cells, neutrophils, and macrophages

feedback.p: Incorrect. Mast cells are part of the allergic and inflammatory responses.
Incorrect. B cells and T cells are part of the adaptive immune response.
Incorrect. Thymus cells are part of the thymus and do not participate in the immune response.
Correct. Those cells are part of the innate response, and PPR react to PAMPs, common markers of pathogens.

body.p: Antigens are molecules that stimulate the adaptive immune response. The small regions of the antigen molecule that are actually stimulatory are referred to as ____________________.

input.choice: Epitopes
Isotopes
Epidermis
Isotype

feedback.p: Correct. Epitopes are short sequences that are recognized by the adaptive response.
Incorrect. Isotopes are variants of an element, presenting different neutron numbers.
Incorrect. Epidermis is a layer of the skin.
Incorrect. Isotype refers to the variety of antibody which is being made by a B cell.

body.p: Your MHC proteins are unique to you and distinguish your cells from any other organism. Being able to recognize self from non-self is important because ______________.

input.choice: Helper T cells need to be able to recognize a protein as foreign.
Cytotoxic T cells recognize cells that have a foreign protein fragment bound to MHC proteins on a cell surface and kill those cells with the abnormal protein.
Macrophages must have the correct MHC markers on their cell surface to function as antigen presenting cells.
All of the above are true.

feedback.p: Partially correct. There are other true statements in the list.
Partially correct. There are other true statements in the list.
Partially correct. There are other true statements in the list.
Correct.

body.p: Antibodies or immunoglobulins have a specific structure that is related to their function. Which of the following statement(s) is/are not true?

input.choice: IgA is dimer usually found in breast milk, tears and saliva.
IgG is a single molecule whose levels increase dramatically when the immune system encounters a pathogen for the second time.
IgM is a pentamer whose levels increase during the immune response following an initial vaccination.
IgE is found only on the surface of B cells.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Indeed, IgA is the antibody found in secretions.
Incorrect, IgG is the single unit antibody that is prominent in the secondary adaptive response.
Incorrect. The large (5 unit) IgN is the first antibody produced during a primary response.
Correct. IgE is not found on B cells.

body.p: Two key classes of cytokines in the immune response are interferons and interleukins, interferons___________ and interleukins______________.

input.choice: Disrupt parasite invasion, stimulate stem cells
Help fight viral infections, physically link together white blood cells
Made by dendritic cells, stimulate macrophages to present antigen
Help macrophages present antigen, stimulate B and T cells to divide

feedback.p: Incorrect. Alpha-interferons are part of the innate response and help fight viral infections.
Incorrect. Interleukins stimulate cell division, they do not link cells.
Incorrect. Interleukins do not stimulate macrophages to present antigens.
Correct. Gamma-interferons stimulate macrophages and lymphocytes.

body.p: Which one of the following cells cannot play a role as an antigen presenting cell?

input.choice: Helper T cells
Dendritic cells
Macrophages
B cells

feedback.p: Correct. Helper T cells respond to antigen which has been presented by another cell in conjunction with MHC proteins.
Incorrect. Dendritic cells can present antigens.
Incorrect. Macrophages are one of the most common antigen presenting cells.
Incorrect. Bcells make antibodies, but they are also capable of presenting antigen in the right circumstance.

body.p: Macrophages can be considered one of the cell types that can act as as bridge between the innate and adaptative immune responses. Which statement correctly expresses both functions?

input.choice: Macrophages clean up cell debris and produce cytokines that stimulate B cells.
Macrophages work with T helper cells and stimulate mast cells.
Macrophages and neutrophils can phagocytize bacterial cells by recognizing specific pattern molecules.
Macrophages release cytokines to stimulate the inflammatory response and present antigens to T-Helper cells.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Cleaning up debris is considered part of the innate response and macrophages do not produce cytokines that directly stimulate B cells.
Incorrect. Macrophages do not stimulate mast cells.
Incorrect. These activities are both part of the innate immune response.
Correct. Macrophages do both.

body.p: During the primary response, a B lymphocyte will recognize a single epitope within an antigen, and the resulting plasma cells will produce specific antibodies against the epitope. Select the correct statement referring to the secondary immune response from the choices below.

input.choice: All memory B cells are stimulated so that a variety of antibodies are secreted by the plasma cells.
The individual plasma B cells switch from making IgM to IgG.
The memory B cells, which recognizes an epitope on the antigen undergoes clonal expansion, so there is a large number of plasma cells producing the appropriate antibody.
NK cells attack and kill any cell expressing the original epitope.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The memory B cells response is specific, so all of the cells are not stimulated.
Incorrect. Once a B cells is committed to produce a specific antibody, it does not switch isotypes.
Correct. After a the specific memory B cell recognizes its antigen, B cells will proliferate and then become plasma cells producing large quantities of the same antibody.
Incorrect. NK cells are part of the innate immune response, not the adaptive.

body.p: Lymphoid tissues can be found in several basic organizational structures: ____________ , where the lymphoid tissues are scattered throughout an area; and dense nodules, which describe the kind of arrangements found in __________________ and ____________________.

input.choice: random, spleen and lymph nodes
diffuse, tonsils and Peyer’s Patches
encapsulated, lymph nodes and thymus
freestanding, thyroid and spleen

feedback.p: Incorrect. The spleen is a lymphoid organ.
Correct. Tonsils and Peyer’s pathcehs are examples of dense nocules.
Incorrect. Encapsulated tissues are discrete structures.
Incorrect. The spleen is a lymphoid organ and the thyroid gland is not a lymphoid organ.

body.p: Lymph circulation differs from blood circulation in which of the following ways?

input.choice: Lymph flows is in one direction only.
Lymph capillaries have a blind end at the tissue level.
Lymph vessels often run parallel to arteries.
A, B, and C are correct.
Only A and B are correct.

feedback.p: Partially correct. While this statement is true it is not the only correct answer.
Partially correct. While this statement is true it is not the only correct answer.
Incorrect. Lymph vessels usually follow veins, not arteries
Incorrect. One of choices A, B and C is not true.
Correct. Lymph flows from blind-ended capillaries to lymph vessels in one direction, often paralleling veins.

body.p: The spleen is both an organ of the circulatory system and of the lymphatic system. If a spleen ruptures and needs to be removed, what would be the most likely consequences of the splenectomy?

input.choice: There would be no blood reservoir and the immune system would not be able to function.
The immune system would not be able to make any new leukocytes or erythrocytes.
The blood volume would be distributed in other regions of the body, and the immune system would be slightly less responsive.
One cannot live without the spleen.

feedback.p: Incorrect. The immune system would be less efficient, but would still function.
Incorrect. The hematopoietic stem cells are located in the bone marrow, not the spleen.
Correct. The spleen is not required for survival.
Incorrect. As long as the bleeding is stopped when the spleen ruptures, one can live without a spleen.

body.p: Which of the following statements regarding lymphomas is correct?

input.choice: Patients with mantle cell lymphoma have a long life expectancy.
The accelerated apoptosis of Diffuse Large B Cell lymphoma (DLBLC) cells is responsible for its aggressive behavior.
All lymphomas arise from different types of leukocytes.
Both DLBCL and follicular lymphomas originate from germinal center cells.
The most common lymphoma is follicular lymphoma.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Mantle cell lymphoma patients have only 2-5 years of life expectancy.
Incorrect. Proliferation and lack of apoptosis of B cells cause DLBCL.
Incorrect. Lymphomas are tumors derived from lymphocytes.
Correct. They originate from germinal centers, which are sites of B cell proliferation the the lymphoid follicles.
Incorrect. The most common lymphoma is DLBCL.

body.p: Which of the following is not an innate defense mechanism?

input.choice: Phagocytosis
Physiological defenses
Anatomic barrier defenses
Antibody production
Fever
Inflammatory response
All are innate defenses

feedback.p: Incorrect. Phagocytosis is an innate defense.
Incorrct, physiological defenses are innate mechanisms.
Incorrect. Anatomic barriers are the first line of innate defense.
Correct. Antibody production is not an innate defense mechanism.
Incorrect. Fever production is an innate defense.
Incorrect. The inflammatory response is considered an innate defense.
Incorrect D is not an innate defense.

body.p: In general, anatomical and physical barriers serve what purpose?

input.choice: Trap, kill, or expel potential pathogens
Lyse, engulf or swallow
Remove, degrade, or expunge
Immobilize, neutralize, or barricade

feedback.p: Correct. This is the purpose served by anatomical and physical barriers.
Incorrect. These are specific mechanisms but not generalized ones
Incorrect. This does not consider trapping them before they enter
Incorrect. This does not include killing or removing them from the body.

body.p: Which cells may be involved in the innate cellular immune response, including the inflammatory response?

input.choice: Macrophages
Dendritic cells
Mast cells
Histocytes
Kupger cells
Neutrophils
A, B,C and F
D and E
All of the above

feedback.p: Incorrect. There are other correct answers.
Incorrect. There are other correct answers.
Incorrect. There are other correct answers.
Incorrect. There are other correct answers.
Incorrect. There are other correct answers.
Incorrect. There are other correct answers.
Incorrect. There are other correct answers.
Incorrect. There are other correct answers.
Correct. All these cells are involved in the innate immune response.

body.p: What stimulates chemotaxis of macrophages to the site of an infection, where they will phagocytize a pathogen?

input.choice: Antibodies
Antigens
Leukotrienes
Inactive complement

feedback.p: Incorrect. Antibodies alone do not stimulate macrophages.
Incorrect. Antigens do directly stimulate macrophage phagocytosis.
Correct. Leukotrienes attract phagocytes.
Incorrect. Activated complement is the stimulant.

body.p: In which choice are the three basic processes of the inflammatory response correctly ordered?

input.choice: Neutrophil phagocytosis, draining of swelling, scar formation
Vasodilation and swelling, emigration of phagocytic cells, wound healing
Increased fluid in the affected tissue, influx of mast cells, scar tissue removal
Vasoconstriction, macrophage invasion, scab formation

feedback.p: Incorrect.There must be vasodilation first so the neutrophils can move in.
Correct. This is the proper order of the inflammatory response processes.
Incorrect. Mast cells are already found in the tissues.
Incorrect. The inflammatory response involves vasodilation not vasoconstriction.

body.p: Innate cellular immunity can be added by the molecules circulating in the blood. The kinin-kallikrein system contributes to _______________ while the ________________ can result in the formation of membrane attack complexes.

input.choice: Antibody formation, activated complement system
Cytokine formation, inteleukons
Blood clotting, opsinization molecules
Vasodilation, activated complement system

feedback.p: Incorrect. Antibody formation is not part of innate immunity.
Incorrect. Interleukins are cells signalling molecules.
Incorrect. Blood clotting does not play a role in innate immunity..
Correct.

body.p: The kinin-kallikrein system results in vasodilation of blood vessels because which following molecules is formed through a protein cascade?

input.choice: Bradykinin
Kinnetokinin
Alpha-Interferon
Cytokine

feedback.p: Correct. The Bradykinin molecule is formed through a protein cascade.
Incorrect kinnetokinin is not a real molecule.
Incorrect. Interferon plays a role in immunity against virally infected cells.
Incorrect. "Cytokine” is a generic name for a group of substances, not one specific molecule.

body.p: Which of the following phrases does NOT correctly describe the role of fever in innate body defense?

input.choice: Fever production is the normal response to pyrogens.
Fever results when the hypothalamic thermostat is reset to a higher temperature.
Fever inhibits the growth of some microbes.
Fever reduces the availability of iron and zinc required for bacterial proliferation.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Pyrogens do indeed result in the hypothalamus resetting its temperature set point.
Incorrect. They pyrogens do rest the hypothalamic set point to a higher temperature.
Incorrect. Raising the body temperature makes it difficult for some microbes to grow since they may have a very narrow ideal temperature range.
Correct. Transferrins do not play a role in fever development.

body.p: The following events refer to the adaptive response against a viral infection. Order the following events from earliest to latest:

li.p: Viral antigen is presented by the infected cell with MHC class I antigen.
The cytotoxic T cell releases perforins and granzymes.
A virus replicates within a body cell.
The TCR (T-cell receptor) of a cytotoxic T cell binds to the MHC class I antigen of the infected cell presenting the viral antigen.
The virally infected cell undergoes apoptosis.

feedback.p: Correct. The virally infected cell will present the viral antigen within its MHC-I, which will be recognized by the cytotoxic T cell, which will release perforins and granzymes provoking apoptosis of the infected cell.

Incorrect. The virally infected cell will present the viral antigen within its MHC-I, which will be recognized by the cytotoxic T cell, which will release perforins and granzymes provoking apoptosis of the infected cell.

Incorrect. The virally infected cell will present the viral antigen within its MHC-I, which will be recognized by the cytotoxic T cell, which will release perforins and granzymes provoking apoptosis of the infected cell.

Incorrect. The virally infected cell will present the viral antigen within its MHC-I, which will be recognized by the cytotoxic T cell, which will release perforins and granzymes provoking apoptosis of the infected cell.

Incorrect. The virally infected cell will present the viral antigen within its MHC-I, which will be recognized by the cytotoxic T cell, which will release perforins and granzymes provoking apoptosis of the infected cell.

body.p: All of the following molecules bind to each other except which one pairing?

input.choice: PAMPs- PRRs
Immunoglobulins-antigens
MHC II antigens-TCR/CD4
B7-CD28
MHC I antigens-BCR

feedback.p: Incorrect. PAMPs expressed by pathogens are recognized by PRRs.
Incorrect. Immunoglobulins (antibodies) bind to specific antigens.
Incorrect. The TCR and CD4 molecules of T helper cells bind to the MHC class II antigens of the antigen presenting cell.
Incorrect. These two costimulatory molecules bind to each other during antigen presentation.
Correct. It is the TCR and CD8 of CD8+ cells that bind to the MHC I antigens of the antigen presenting cell.

body.p: What is the role of interferon in defense against disease?

input.choice: protects cells that have not yet been infected by bacteria
protects cells that have not yet been infected by viruses
activates the complement mechanism
activates the inflammatory process

feedback.p: Incorrect. Interferons play a role in antiviral defenses.
Correct. Interferons play a role in antiviral defenses.
Incorrect. Interferons play a role in antiviral defenses.
Incorrect. Interferons play a role in antiviral defenses.

body.p: Which of the following is not a role of activated complement?

input.choice: prevention of allergic reactions
insertion of MAC and cell lysis
opsonization
enhancement of inflammation

feedback.p: Correct. Complement is not involved in allergies.
Incorrect. Cell lysis through MAC formation is a role of complement.
Incorrect. Opsonization to make phagocytosis more effective is a role of complement.
Incorrect. Many components of the complement cascade are inflammatory mediators.

body.p: Which of the following does NOT increase blood vessel permeability?

input.choice: Leukotrienes
Histamine
Prostaglandins
Kinins
Lysozyme

feedback.p: Incorrect. Leukotrienes do increase blood vessel permeability.
Incorrect. Histamine does increase blood vessel permeability.
Incorrect. prostaglandins do increase blood vessel permeabilityP
Incorrect. Kinins do increase blood vessel permeability.
Correct. Lysozyme degrades the bacterial cell wall, but does not affect blood vessel permeability.

body.p: Which of the following is NOT a function of inflammation?

input.choice: disposes of cellular debris and pathogens
sets the stage for repair processes
replaces injured tissues with connective tissue
Prevents the spread of the injurious agent to nearby tissue

feedback.p: Incorrect. This is one function of inflammation.
Incorrect. This is one function of inflammation.
Correct. Inflammation sets the stage for repair but the repair itself is mainly done by fibroblasts.
Incorrect. This is one function of inflammation.

body.p: Which of the following statements regarding NK cells is a false or incorrect statement?

input.choice: NK cells attack cells that display abnormal MHC antigens.
NK cells are a type of neutrophil.
NK cells are present in the blood, spleen, lymph nodes, and red bone marrow.
NK cells attack cancer cells and virus-infected body cells.
NK cells can provoke cell “suicide” through perforins and granzymes.

feedback.p: Incorrect. NK cells do attack cells with no normal MHC antigens.
Correct. Indeed NK cells are a special type of lymphocytes.
Incorrect. NK cells do abound in all those locations.
Incorrect. The main function of NK cells is to fight virus-infected and cancer cells.
Incorrect. NK cells do provoke apoptosis through perforins and granzymes.

body.p: What is innate immunity?

input.choice: The body's ability to ward off diseases.
Increased susceptibility to disease.
The lack of resistance.
The body's defense against a particular pathogen.
The body's defenses against any kind of pathogen.

feedback.p: Incorrect. That would be immunity in general.
Incorrect. Immunity refers to defenses not susceptibility.
Incorrect. That would be tolerance.
Incorrect. That would be adaptive immunity.
Correct. Innate immunity recognizes characteristics common to most pathogens.

body.p: Which of the following determine(s) what specific foreign substances our adaptive immune system will be able to recognize and resist?

input.choice: Enzymes present at the time of the invasion
Our genes
The type of antigen
Memory cell production
Our overall health state

feedback.p: Incorrect. Enzymes have no role in immune recognition.
Correct. Our genes determine what is “self” and the immune system will respond to everything “non-self.”
Incorrect. The type will determine only the kind of response.
Incorrect. Memory cells just make an immune response more effective.
Incorrect. That may affect only the intensity of the response.

body.p: Which of the statements below does not describe antigens?

input.choice: Antigens can include proteins, nucleic acids, lipoproteins, glycoproteins, and certain large polysaccharides.
Antigens only come from microbes.
Antigens are bound by immune cell receptors and antibodies.
The parts of antigen molecules that initiate immune responses are called epitopes or antigenic determinants.
An antibody could be an antigen also.

feedback.p: Incorrect. Those are all possible antigenic molecules.
Correct. An antigen is a molecule perceived as non-self- could be in a transplanted cell or be part of a cancer cell.
Incorrect. Antigens are bound by T and B cell receptors.
Incorrect. Epitopes are indeed the regions in antigens recognized by the immune cells.
Incorrect. An antibody would be an antigen for another individual and/or species. If a human antibody is injected into a rabbit, the rabbit will produce anti-human Ig antibodies.

body.p: Which is the best definition of an antibody?

input.choice: An immunoglobulin.
A serum protein.
A protein made in response to an antigen that can combine with that antigen.
A protein that combines with a protein or carbohydrate.
A protein that inactivates or kills an antigen.

feedback.p: Incorrect. While antibodies are immunoglobulins, this is not the best definition.
Incorrect. While antibodies are serum proteins, this is not the best definition.
Correct. This summarizes how antibodies are produced and what is their function.
Incorrect. While antibodies can combine with proteins and carbohydrates, this is not the best definition as other proteins can do the same.
Incorrect. While antibodies can inactivate antigens (not killing as they are not alive), this is not the best definition because other proteins can do so.
